case_name: Maulana Abdul Shakoor v. Rikhab Chand Jain

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 335 of 1957 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 335 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 31, 1957 of Election Tribunal Ajmer in Election Petition No. 2 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1957, of the Election Tribunal, Ajmer, in Election Petition No. 2 of 1956. Mukat Beha

facts.text: Maulana Abdul Shakoor elected to Council of States by Electoral College of Ajmer consisting of 30 members constituting State Legislature of Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the order of the Election Tribunal dated January 31, 1957, setting aside the election of the appellant, Maulana Abdul Shakoor, who was elected to the Council of States by the Electoral College of Ajmer which companysisted of 30 members companystituting the State Legislature of Ajmer.

facts.text: Appellant received 19 votes against 7 votes for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: He received 19 votes as against 7 polled in favour of the other candidate who is respondent No. 1 in this appeal. The total number of valid votes polled was 26 and there were 3 invalid votes.

facts.text: Total valid votes polled: 26, invalid votes: 3.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of valid votes polled was 26 and there were 3 invalid votes. The result of the election was published in the Official Gazette on March 31, 1957, declaring the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Election result published in Official Gazette on March 31, 1957 declaring appellant elected.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the election was published in the Official Gazette on March 31, 1957, declaring the election of the appellant. The unsuccessful candidate, the present first respondent, filed his election petition on May 2, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed election petition on May 2, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The unsuccessful candidate, the present first respondent, filed his election petition on May 2, 1956. It is number necessary to set out all the allegations in the petition because the main companytroversy between the parties is whether the successful candidate, the present appellant, held an office of profit under the Government.

facts.text: Impugned election held on March 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned election was held on March 22, 1956. By a numberification issued on February 17, 1956, the numberinations for candidature were to be filed between February 28, 1956, and March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Notification issued on February 17, 1956 for nominations between February 28 and March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification issued on February 17, 1956, the numberinations for candidature were to be filed between February 28, 1956, and March 1, 1956. The date for scrutiny was March 5, 1956, and for the polling March 22, 1956.

facts.text: Scrutiny date: March 5, 1956; polling: March 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The date for scrutiny was March 5, 1956, and for the polling March 22, 1956. The appellant filed two numberination papers on February 28, 1956, and a third one on March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant filed two nomination papers on February 28, 1956 and third on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed two numberination papers on February 28, 1956, and a third one on March 1, 1956. The respondent Rikhab Chand Jain also filed his numberination papers on March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent Rikhab Chand Jain filed nomination papers on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Rikhab Chand Jain also filed his numberination papers on March 1, 1956. On March 5, 1956, the respondent Rikhab Chand Jain raised certain objections to the validity of the appellants numberination, the main ground being that the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government.

facts.text: On March 5, 1956, respondent raised objections to appellant's nomination on ground of holding office of profit under Government.

anchor.surface_text: On March 5, 1956, the respondent Rikhab Chand Jain raised certain objections to the validity of the appellants numberination, the main ground being that the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government.

facts.text: Returning Officer by order dated March 6, 1956 rejected two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 but accepted the one of March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer by his order dated March 6, 1956, rejected the two numberination papers of the appellant filed on February 28, 1956, but accepted the third one, i.e., of March 1, 1956, because, according to that officer, under the provisions of Durgah Khwaja Saheb  Emeregency Provisions  Act, 1950  XVII of 1950  which was in force up to February 29, 1956, the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government but on the companying into force of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXXVI of 1955  on March 1, 1956, he numberlonger held such office under the Government.

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act 1950 in force up to February 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: ...under the provisions of Durgah Khwaja Saheb  Emeregency Provisions  Act, 1950  XVII of 1950  which was in force up to February 29, 1956, the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government...

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act 1955 came into force on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: ...but on the companying into force of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXXVI of 1955  on March 1, 1956, he numberlonger held such office under the Government. On May 3, 1956, the respondent filed an election petition under s. 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951...

facts.text: Election Tribunal majority by order January 31, 1957 held appellant held office of profit under Government on March 1, 1956, set aside election, declared respondent elected.

anchor.surface_text: A majority of the Election Tribunal by their order dated January 31, 1957, held that on March 1, 1956, the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government and therefore his numberination paper was hit by Art. 102 1   a  of the Constitution. They set aside his election and accepting the companytention as to thrown away votes declared the respondent elected.

facts.text: Chairman of Election Tribunal dissented, held no office of profit under Government on March 1, 1956, election valid.

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with the majority, the Chairman of the Election Tribunal held that on March 1, 1956, the appellant was numberlonger holding an office of profit under the Government, his numberination paper was rightly accepted and his election was valid and therefore the respondent companyld number be declared elected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal unanimously held two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 invalid as appellant held office of profit on that date.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the two numberination papers of the appellant dated February 28, 1956, were valid or number the Tribunal unanimously held them to be invalid on the ground that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government on that date.

facts.text: Appellant appointed honorary mohatmin (manager) of Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari on February 28, 1955 by Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1955, the appellant was given an honorary appointment of mohatmin  manager  of the school by the Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb. He was to work under the Administrator and was to hold charge of the management of the school.

facts.text: From May 1955, appellant paid Rs. 100 per month as salary/honorarium.

anchor.surface_text: But from May 1955 he was being paid Rs. 100 per month which has been variously described as salary and honorarium.

facts.text: Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari is a school for Persian, Arabic and Muslim theology; before 1951 managed by Government of Nizam of Hyderabad; 1951 taken over by Durgah Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari in which the appellant held the appointment of a manager  mohatmin  is a school for teaching Persian, Arabic and Muslim theology. Before 1951 it was managed and run by the Government of the Nizam of Hyderabad. In 1951 this school was taken over by the Durgah Committee.

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act 1955 received assent of President on October 14, 1955, came into force March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1950 was replaced by the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXXVI of 1955  which, received the assent of the President on October 14, 1955, but came into force oil March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds appellant not holding office of profit under Government of India on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the majority of the Tribunal has erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government and the opinion of the Chairman to the companytrary lays down the companyrect position.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Tribunal order, allows appeal, holds appellant's election valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Before and up to 1936 the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Endowment was administered by a committee which was constituted by the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer under s. 7 of the Religious Endowments Act  XX of 1863 .

In 1936 the then Central Legislature enacted the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXIII of 1936 . By the provisions of that Act the management and administration was vested in Durgah Committee constituted under s. 4 of the Act.

issues.text: was the appellant holding an office of profit under the Government of India and does Art. 102 1 a of the Constitution operate ?

anchor.surface_text: In order to resolve this controversy the important question of construction that arises is was the appellant holding an office of profit under the Government of India and does Art. 102 1 a of the Constitution operate ?

issues.text: whether the two nomination papers filed by the appellant on February 28, 1956, were valid or not

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the two nomination papers of the appellant dated February 28, 1956, were valid or not the Tribunal unanimously held them to be invalid on the ground that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government on that date. It is not necessary to go into the question whether the two nomination papers filed by the appellant on February 28, 1956, were valid or not

anchor.surface_text: It has not been shown that the appellants appointment as a mohatmin (manager) of the school satisfies any of the tests which have been discussed above. On the other hand on March 1, 1956,

holdings.text: The appellant did not hold an office of profit under the Government of India on March 1, 1956, as his appointment was under the Durgah Committee, a statutory body corporate, and Article 102(1)(a) does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: It has not been shown that the appellants appointment as a mohatmin (manager) of the school satisfies any of the tests which have been discussed above. On the other hand on March 1, 1956,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment by statutory committee, not directly by government; no government power of removal or payment from government revenues; contrasts with direct government offices.

holdings.text: The power of the Government to appoint, continue, or revoke an office at discretion and payment from government revenues are important factors to determine an office of profit under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenues are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizes constitutional language, prior cases, and facts; applies multi-factor test excluding statutory body appointments.

holdings.text: Servants of the Durgah Committee do not hold office of profit under the Government merely because the Government appoints or can remove Committee members or approves bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the Committee or the members of the Committee are removeable by the Government of India or the Committee can make bye-laws prescribing the duties and powers of its employees cannot in our opinion convert the servants of the Committee into holders of office of profit under the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee is independent body corporate; government control over committee does not extend to direct control over its servants.

holdings.text: Article 102(1)(a) disqualifies only for offices of profit directly under Government of India or State, unlike Articles 58(2) and 66(4) which include offices under local/other authorities subject to government control.

anchor.surface_text: A comparison of the different articles of the Constitution 58 2 , 66 4 , 102 1  a  and 19 1  1  a  dealing with membership of the State Legislatures shows in the case of members of the Legislatures unlike the case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison shows deliberate narrower language for legislators vs executive offices.

holdings.text: The majority of the Election Tribunal erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government; the Chairman's contrary opinion is correct.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the majority of the Tribunal has erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government and the opinion of the Chairman to the contrary lays down the correct position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies tests to facts; endorses lower tribunal dissent over majority.

holdings.text: The appellant's election is valid; the Tribunal's order setting it aside is wrong; appeal allowed and Tribunal majority order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holding on Article 102(1)(a); no need to address other issues.

holdings.text: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank does not apply to determine office under Government.

anchor.surface_text: But that again has no application to the facts of the present case because the appellant has not been employed by a servant of the Government who is authorised to employ servants for doing some service for the Government nor is he paid out of Indian revenues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes on facts: no government servant appointing for government service from government funds.

precedents.citation: Shivnandan Sharma v. The, Punjab National Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Shivnandan Sharma v. The, Punjab National Bank Ltd. 1 . That was a case under the Industrial Disputes Act and the question for decision was whether a cashier appointed by the Banks treasurer on behalf of the Bank and paid by the Bank was a servant of the Bank.

precedents.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: if the master employs a servant and authorises him to employ a number of persons to do a particular job and to guarantee their fidelity and efficiency for cash consideration, the employees thus appointed by the servant would be, equally with the servant, servants of the master
precedents.cited_holding: a cashier appointed by the Bank's treasurer on behalf of the Bank and paid by the Bank was a servant of the Bank

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, order of the majority of the Election Tribunal set aside, appellant's election upheld
directions: set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: It has not been shown that the appellants appointment as a mohatmin (manager) of the school satisfies any of the tests which have been discussed above. On the other hand on March 1, 1956,
We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenues are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government
We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

Merely because the Committee or the members of the Committee are removeable by the Government of India or the Committee can make bye-laws prescribing the duties and powers of its employees cannot in our opinion convert the servants of the Committee into holders of office of profit under the Government of India.
We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

In the circumstances the majority of the Tribunal has erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government and the opinion of the Chairman to the contrary lays down the correct position.
We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

edges.explanation: Resolving Feb 28 nomination validity requires application of then-in-force 1950 Act Section 3

Determining validity of nomination papers requires considering Section 7 of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act regarding the Administrator being under direct control of Central Government, as it relates to office of profit disqualification.
